revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Sejdefu majka buđaše''''' (English: ''Seydefa's Mother Wakes Her'') is a [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnian]]<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.info-ks.net/clanak.php?id=23173&naziv=turkinja-pjeva-%E2%80%9Csejdefu-majka-budjase%E2%80%9D-&nav_id=5&pod_nav=29|title=Turkinja pjeva "Sejdefu majka buđaše"|publisher=Info-ks|date=1 November 2012|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://portalanalitika.me/drustvo/vijesti/79053-strunjaci-tvrde-sejdefa-ne-moe-biti-dio-srpskog-muzikog-nasljea-.html|title="Sejdefa" ne može biti dio srpskog muzičkog nasljeđa|publisher=PortalAnalitika|date=2 November 2012|accessdate=14 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121205150747/http://www.portalanalitika.me/drustvo/vijesti/79053-strunjaci-tvrde-sejdefa-ne-moe-biti-dio-srpskog-muzikog-nasljea-.html|archivedate=5 December 2012|df=}}</ref> traditional folk and [[sevdalinka]] song.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.folkoteka.com/2012/11/sevdalinka-sejdefu-majka-budase-u-seriji-sulejman-velicanstveni-video/|title=Sevdalinka "Sejdefu majka buđaše" u seriji "Sulejman Veličanstveni"|publisher=Folkoteka|date=|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://vlasenica.org/index.php/na-na-nain/kultura/991-video-qsejdefu-majka-buaeq-u-seriji-qsulejman-velianstveniq|title="Sejdefu majka buđaše" u seriji "Sulejman veličanstveni"|publisher=Vlasenica|date=21 November 2012|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.vesti-online.com/Scena/Soubiznis/266279/Turkinja-sa-Kosova-peva-na-srpskom-u-Sulejmanu|title=Turkinja sa Kosova peva na srpskom u "Sulejmanu"|publisher=Vesti-online|date=1 November 2012|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref>
==Origins== ''Sejdefu majka buđaše'' is a [[traditional song|traditional]] song that is believed to have originated in [[Sarajevo]] centuries ago, while the region of [[Bosnia (region)|Bosnia]] was a part of the [[Ottoman Empire]].<ref>{{cite news|author=|url=http://portalanalitika.me/drustvo/vijesti/79053-strunjaci-tvrde-sejdefa-ne-moe-biti-dio-srpskog-muzikog-nasljea-.html#CommentForm|title=Stručnjaci tvrde: "Sejdefa" ne može biti dio srpskog muzičkog nasljeđa|date=2 November 2012|accessdate=13 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121205150747/http://www.portalanalitika.me/drustvo/vijesti/79053-strunjaci-tvrde-sejdefa-ne-moe-biti-dio-srpskog-muzikog-nasljea-.html#CommentForm|archivedate=5 December 2012|df=}}</ref> The exact author is unknown.
Over the centuries, the song spread amongst the [[Bosniak]] populations in [[Podgorica]] and the [[Sandžak]] regions of [[Montenegro]] and [[Serbia]].
==Lyrics== {| ! width="50%" | Original ! width="50%" | English translation |- | valign="top" | :''Sejdefu majka buđaše :''ustani kćeri moja, Sejdefo
:''Zar misliš majko :''da ja spim
:''ja ti se mlada s dušom dijelim
:''zovi mi majko komšije :''i prvo moje gledanje
:''što smo se majko gledali :''u šajku lađu na more
| valign="top" |
:''Sejdefa's mother wakes her :''Rise, my daughter Sejdefa!
:''Do you think, mother :''that I'm asleep?
:''At this young age, I'm parting with my soul.
:''Call the neighbors, mother :''And my first love.
:''The one whose eyes met mine :''On a boat out at sea. |}
==Covers== {{col-begin}} | width="50%" align="left" valign="top" style="border:0"| *[[Sinan Alimanović]] *[[Amira Medunjanin]] *[[Ana Bekuta]] *[[Hanka Paldum]] *Ksenija Cicvarić<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.discogs.com/Ksenija-Cicvari%C4%87-Sejdefu-Majka-Bu%C4%91a%C5%A1e/release/3229960|title=Ksenija Cicvarić – Sejdefu majka buđaše|publisher=Discogs|date=|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref> *[[Lepa Brena]] *[[Merima Njegomir]]<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.medio.rs/48943_Turkinja-sa-Kosova-zapevala-na-srpskom-u-Sulejmanu-Velicanstvenom!-.html|title=Turkinja sa Kosova zapevala na srpskom u Sulejmanu Veličanstvenom!|publisher=Medio|date=1 November 2012|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref> | width="50%" align="left" valign="top" style="border:0"| *[[Neda Ukraden]] *[[Silvana Armenulić]]<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.telegraf.rs/jetset/401648-turkinja-sa-kosova-zapevala-na-srpskom-u-sulejmanu-velicanstvenom-video|title=Turkinja sa Kosova zapevala na srpskom u Sulejmanu Veličanstvenom!|publisher=Telegraf|date=1 November 2012|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.discogs.com/Silvana-Armenuli%C4%87-I-Aleksandar-Trandafilovi%C4%87-Mujo-%C5%A0alje-Haber-Sa-Mjeseca/release/2555649|title=Silvana Armenulić i Aleksandar Trandafilović - Mujo šalje haber sa mjeseca|publisher=Discogs|date=11 May 1967|accessdate=19 October 2012}}</ref> *Snežana Đurišić *Suzan Kardeş<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.bljesak.info/web/article.aspx?a=bf8568fb-e22a-49e1-bd42-57ae1b88a290&c=5de70792-d2d5-4648-8125-5206af0d3357|title=Bosanskohercegovačka sevdalinka u seriji ''Sulejman Veličanstveni''|publisher=Bljesak|date=2 November 2012|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref> *[[Zehra Deović]] {{col-end}}
==In popular culture== It was sung by [[Republic of Kosovo|Kosovo]]-born singer Suzan Kardeş on the Turkish soap opera ''[[Muhteşem Yüzyıl]]'' (called ''Sulejman Veličanstveni'' in the [[former Yugoslavia|former Yugoslav]] countries and ''Magnificent Century'' in [[English language|English]]) in the 44th episode of the series that aired in January 2012.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.haber.ba/showbiz/televizija/22119-sejdefu-majka-budjase-otpjevana-u-sulejmanu-velicanstvenom-na-nasem-jeziku-video.html|title="Sejdefu majka buđaše" otpjevana u "Sulejmanu veličanstvenom" na našem jeziku!|publisher=Haber|date=1 November 2012|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.alo.rs/v-i-p/estrada/turkinja-sa-kosova-peva-na-srpskom-u-sulejmanu-video/3192|title=Turkinja sa Kosova peva na srpskom u "Sulejmanu"! |publisher=Alo|date=1 November 2012|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.kurir-info.rs/sulejman-proterao-hurem-clanak-278400|title=Sulejman proterao Hurem!|publisher=Kurir-info|date=17 June 2012|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of Bosnia and Herzegovina folk songs]] *[[Sevdalinka]] *''[[Emina (poem)|Emina]]'' *''[[Moj dilbere]]''

{{Infobox person | name = Ted Hartley | image = Ted Hartley Chopper One cast 1974 (cropped).JPG | caption = Ted Hartley in ''[[Chopper One]]'', 1974. | birth_name = Theodore Ringwalt Hartley | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1924|11|6}} | birth_place = [[Omaha, Nebraska]], U.S. | alma mater = [[U.S. Naval Academy]]
[[Harvard Business School]] | years_active = 1945–present | occupation = Fighter pilot, actor, businessman, film and stage producer | spouse = {{marriage|[[Dina Merrill]]|1989|2017|end=died}} | website = {{URL|http://tedhartley.com}} }} '''Theodore Ringwalt Hartley''' (born November 6, 1924) is a US Navy fighter pilot, investment banker, actor, film producer, and is currently CEO of [[RKO Pictures]]. He was married to heiress, actress and philanthropist [[Dina Merrill]]{{cite web|url=http://www.tedhartley.com/articles/article%20-%20people.pdf|title=Encore, Encore: Now behind the camera, Dina Merrill and Ted Hartley make movie magic together|author=Samantha Miller, Danelle Morton and Vicki Sheff-Cahan|date=April 19, 1999|work= People magazine|publisher= People magazine|accessdate=April 19, 2012}} until her death in 2017. ==Early life== {{unsourced|section|date=December 2018}} Hartley was born in [[Omaha, Nebraska]] and raised on a farm in [[Iowa]]. His father died when he was 5, causing financial hardships for the family. At the age of 14, he entered a contest sponsored by [[Warner Bros.]], wrote a 50-word essay on “Why I like to fly”, and won some flying lessons. Hartley attended [[Shattuck Military School]] in [[Minnesota]], and by the age of '''16''' he had won an appointment to the [[U.S. Naval Academy]]. After flight training, among other tours, he served as a [[aircraft carrier|carrier]]-based [[fighter pilot]], flying [[F-11 Tiger|F-11]]s following their introduction in 1956. ==Career== As a Navy officer, Hartley had tours as a congressional liaison for the Pentagon, as a Presidential aide, as well as a carrier-based fighter pilot. In May 1964, his [[F9F Cougar | F9F8]] fighter crashed during a carrier landing accident. He was thrown from the jet, suffered a broken back, and was medically retired from the Navy. Hartley's military career prematurely ended, he attended [[Harvard Business School]] and pursued a career in investment banking, becoming Vice President for First Western Financial Corporation. His next career was in [[Hollywood]], as an actor, where he took on the role of Reverend Jerry Bedford on the 1960s television series ''[[Peyton Place (TV series)|Peyton Place]]''. Hartley had minor roles in films with [[Cary Grant]], [[Robert Redford]] and [[Clint Eastwood]], and then in the late 1970s was cast in his own series, ABC's ''[[Chopper One]]'', about helicopter flying police officers. The series was short lived, and thereafter Hartley moved to [[Aspen, Colorado]], where he volunteered as the Managing Artistic Director of the local theater, and then turned to [[commodity trading]] full-time.{{cn|date=December 2018}} In 1987 he became involved with Pavilion Communications Inc., a company designed to acquire smaller entertainment companies. Through this, Hartley learned of an opportunity to take over [[RKO Pictures]]. He and his wife, [[Dina Merrill]], purchased 51% of the company and merged Pavilion Communications with RKO Pictures Corporation in 1991, forming [[RKO Pictures | RKO Pictures, LLC]]. Their first major project was the 1998 remake of ''[[Mighty Joe Young (1998 film)|Mighty Joe Young]]''. As chairman and chief executive office of RKO Pictures, Hartley has led RKO's worldwide development and production activities in movies and television as well as the expansion of the RKO brand to stage and other entertainment and distribution venues. He produced a remake of ''[[Mighty Joe Young (1998 film)|Mighty Joe Young]]'' (1998) with Disney, ''[[Ritual]]'' (2000) with Miramax, a remake of ''[[The Magnificent Ambersons (2002 film)|The Magnificent Ambersons]]'' (2002), and ''[[Shade (film)|Shade]]'' (2003). For RKO Stage, he produced the musicals ''[[Never Gonna Dance]]'' (2003), ''[[Curtains (musical)|Curtains]]'' (2007), ''[[Gypsy (musical)|Gypsy]]'' (2008), ''[[13 (musical)|13]]'' (2008), all on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]], and ''[[Top Hat (musical)|Top Hat]]'' (2012) in the [[West End theatre|West End]], winner of the 2013 [[Laurence Olivier Award]] for Best New Musical.{{cite web|title=Olivier Award Winners 2013 – Best New Musical|url=http://www.olivierawards.com/winners/view/item216388/olivier-winners-2013|website=olivierawards|accessdate=September 24, 2015|date=April 28, 2013}} In 2013, he was appointed chairman of the board of [[Orbis International]], a nonprofit eye-healthcare organization dedicated to saving sight worldwide that he has been involved with since 2010.{{cite web|last1=Bogusz|first1=Christopher|title=Ted Hartley appointed chairman of Orbis International board of directors|url=http://www.orbis.org/news/entry/ted-hartley-appointed-chairman-of-orbis-international-board-of-directors|website=Orbis|accessdate=November 21, 2014|date=August 6, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129145010/http://www.orbis.org/news/entry/ted-hartley-appointed-chairman-of-orbis-international-board-of-directors|archive-date=2014-11-29|dead-url=yes|df=}} Hartley belongs to a number of motion picture and television guilds and associations, is a board member of the Steadman Philippon Research Institute (formerly, Steadman-Hawkins Sports Medicine Foundation), and serves as director of the Harvard Business School Association of Southern California. He and Merrill founded the Story Project® to promote literacy among inner-city youth, beginning in the Santa Monica Boys and Girls Club. Hartley is also a frequent lecturer and is published periodically in business journals. He is also a published poet as well as a creator of stories for the screen.{{cite web|last1=Hartley|first1=Ted|title=Life Notes, Biography|url=http://tedhartley.com/life-notes|website=tedhartley.com|accessdate=July 20, 2016}} ===Producer credits=== ====Film==== *''[[Barely Lethal]]'' (producer) *''[[A Late Quartet]]'' (producer) *''[[Beyond a Reasonable Doubt]]'' (producer) *''[[Are We Done Yet?]]'' (producer) *''Laura Smiles'' (producer) *''Shade'' (producer) *[[The Gin Game#Adaptations|''The Gin Game'']] (executive producer) *''The Magnificent Ambersons'' (executive producer) *''Ritual'' (producer) *''[[Mighty Joe Young (1998 film)|Mighty Joe Young]]'' (producer) *''[[Milk & Money]]'' (producer) *''[[False Identity]]'' (executive producer) *''Women And Men: Stories Of Seduction'' (executive producer) ====Stage Productions==== * ''Never Gonna Dance'' - 2003 Broadway musical * ''Curtains'' - 2007 Broadway musical * ''Gypsy'' - 2008 Broadway musical (revival starring Patti Lupone) * ''13'' - 2008 Broadway musical * ''Top Hat'' - 2012 West End Musical ===Actor credits=== ====Film==== *''[[Walk, Don't Run]]'' (1966) - Yuri Andreyovitch *''[[Murderers' Row (film)|Murderers' Row]]'' (1966) - Guard *''[[Barefoot in the Park (film)|Barefoot in the Park]]'' (1967) - Frank *''[[Ice Station Zebra]]'' (1968) - Lt. Jonathan Hansen *''[[The Man (1972 film)|The Man]]'' (1972) - Press Secretary *''[[High Plains Drifter]]'' (1973) - Lewis Belding *''[[Aloha, Bobby and Rose]]'' (1975) - Cop *''[[Moving Violation (film)|Moving Violation]]'' (1976) - Prosecutor *''[[Matilda (1978 film)|Matilda]]'' (1978) - Payne Smith *''[[Caddyshack II]]'' (1988) - Club Member *''[[False Identity]]'' (1990) - Inn Keeper *''[[The Player (film)|The Player]]'' (1992) - Party Guest (uncredited) *''Milk & Money'' (1996) - Lingerie Salesman *''[[Shade (film)|Shade]]'' (2003) - 'Teddy' The Surgeon *''Laura Smiles'' (2005) - Therapist *''[[Race to Witch Mountain]]'' (2009) - Four-Star General V. Lewton *''[[A Late Quartet]]'' (2012) - Winning Bidder ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.tedhartley.com/ Personal website] * {{IMDb name|0366894}} * {{IBDB name|109902}} * [http://www.josephdisante.com/article.aspx?pg=Ted%20Hartley "Ted Hartley...and the Rebirth of RKO Studios"] * [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m5072/is_27_24/ai_91092302 "Flight of Fancy: Ted Hartley, who came to Hollywood as an actor and left for investing, has found running the legendary RKO studio rife with challenges"], July 8, 2002, ''[[Los Angeles Business Journal]]'' * ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine, April 19, 1999 [http://www.tedhartley.com/articles/article%20-%20people.pdf (pdf)] * [http://www.tedhartley.com/articles/article%20-%20US%20Naval%20Academy.pdf U.S. Naval Academy Alumni Association newsletter, "Ted Hartley '46" (PDF)] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hartley, Ted}} [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American male film actors]] [[Category:American male television actors]] [[Category:American film producers]] [[Category:American chief executives]] [[Category:Age controversies]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]]

{{Infobox ethnic group| | group = '''Tenggerese people'''
'''{{jav|ꦮꦺꦴꦁꦡꦼꦁꦒꦼꦂ}}/ {{jav|ꦠꦶꦪꦁꦡꦼꦁꦒꦼꦂ}}/{{jav|ꦥꦿꦶꦪꦤ꧀ꦠꦸꦤ꧀ꦡꦼꦁꦒꦼꦂ}}'''
wång Thěnggěr/ tiyang Thěnggěr/ priyantun Thěnggěr | image = [[File:AnakTengger.jpg|250px]] | caption =Tenggerese children from [[Central Java]] | population = 100,000{{cite web|url=http://joshuaproject.net/people_groups/15341/ID |title=Tengger in Indonesia |publisher=[[Joshua Project]] |accessdate=2015-10-05}} | popplace = {{flag|Indonesia}} ([[East Java]]) | langs = [[Javanese language]] ([[Tenggerese dialect]]), [[Indonesian language]] | rels = [[Hinduism]] ([[Shaivism]]) (predominantly), [[Islam]],{{cite web|url=https://m.tempo.co/read/news/2015/12/26/058730740/begini-perayaan-natal-dan-maulid-nabi-di-kawasan-tengger |title=Begini Perayaan Natal dan Maulid Nabi di Kawasan Tengger |author=David Priyasidharta |publisher=Tempo|date=26 December 2015 |accessdate=2016-11-26}} [[Christianity]], [[Buddhism]] | related = other [[Javanese people|Javanese]] sub-ethnic such as [[Mataram Sultanate|Mataram]], [[Cirebonese]], [[Osing people|Osing]], [[Bawean|Boyanese]], [[Samin people|Samin]], [[Kampung Naga|Naganese]], [[Banyumasan people|Banyumasan]], etc.{{cite web|url=http://sp2010.bps.go.id/files/ebook/kewarganegaraan%20penduduk%20indonesia/index.html|title=Index|publisher=sp2010.bps.go.id}} }} {{Javanese script}} The '''Tenggerese''' (''Ngoko'' [[Javanese script|Javanese]]: {{Jav|ꦮꦺꦴꦁꦡꦼꦁꦒꦼꦂ}},Kamus Pepak Basa Jawa,Sudaryanto/Pranowo, 2001, #1359 ''Madya'' [[Javanese script|Javanese]]: {{Jav|ꦠꦶꦪꦁꦡꦼꦁꦒꦼꦂ}},See: [[Javanese language#Politeness|Javanese language: Politeness]] ''Krama'' [[Javanese script|Javanese]]: {{Jav|ꦥꦿꦶꦪꦤ꧀ꦠꦸꦤ꧀ꦡꦼꦁꦒꦼꦂ}},See: [[Javanese language#Politeness|Javanese language: Politeness]] ''Ngoko'' [[Javanese language|Gêdrìk]]: '''wòng Tĕnggĕr''', ''Madya'' [[Javanese language|Gêdrìk]]: '''tiyang Tĕnggĕr''', ''Krama'' [[Javanese language|Gêdrìk]]: '''priyantun Tĕnggĕr''', [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]]: '''''suku Tengger'''''){{Cite book | last = Harjawiyana | first = Haryana | author2 = Theodorus Supriya | title = Kamus unggah-ungguh basa Jawa | publisher = Kanisius | year = 2001 | pages = 185 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=-NOupFY-YTAC&pg=PA185 | isbn = 978-979-672-991-3 }} people are a [[Javanese people|Javanese]] ethnic group in eastern Java who claim to be the descendants of the [[Majapahit]] princes. Their population of roughly 100,000 is centered in 30 villages in the isolated Tengger mountains ([[Mount Bromo]]) in the [[Bromo Tengger Semeru National Park]] in eastern [[Java (island)|Java]]. Scattered communities of Tenggerese also exist in the [[Pasuruan Regency|Pasuruan]], [[Probolinggo Regency|Probolinggo]], [[Malang Regency|Malang]], and [[Lumajang Regency|Lumajang]] [[Regencies of Indonesia|Regencies]] of eastern Java. They are traditionally believed to be the descendants of legendary Roro Anteng and Joko Seger.[http://www.eastjava.com/tourism/malang/mount-bromo.html Mount Bromo] East Java tourism The Tenggerese are considered an ethnic sub-group of the [[Javanese people]]. ==History== Before the 15th century, the past of the Tenggerese was linked with the [[Majapahit]] and other kingdoms from the earlier period. According to legend, Jaka Seger and Roro Anteng are the ancestors of the Tenggerese.{{cite book|author=James Minahan|title=Ethnic Groups of South Asia and the Pacific: An Encyclopedia|year=2012|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=15-988-4660-4|page=}} ==Language== The Tenggerese speak an archaic [[Javanese language|Javanese]] (Majapahit) dialect called [[Tenggerese dialect|Tengger Javanese]]. Elements of modern Javanese influences can be heard in their speech. They have their own written [[Kavi script|Kavi]] script based on the old Javanese [[Brāhmī script|Brahmi]] type.{{cite book|editor=Frank Webster Price|contribution=P.F. Collier & Son Corporation|title=Collier's Encyclopedia: With Bibliography and Index, Volume 10|year=1950|publisher=Collier|isbn=|page=510}} ==Religion== [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Priesters uit het Tengger district Oost-Java TMnr 10001180.jpg|thumb|right|Tengger priests during the [[Dutch East Indies]] era.]] The Tenggerese generally profess [[Hinduism]] as their religion, although they have incorporated many [[Buddhist]] and [[Animist]] elements. Like the [[Balinese people|Balinese]], they worship Ida Sang Hyang Widi Wasa (roughly "Big Almighty Lord") for blessings in addition to other [[Hindu]] and [[Buddhist]] gods that include the Tri Murti ([[Shiva]], [[Brahma]], [[Vishnu]]) and [[Gautama Buddha|Buddha]]. Their places of worship include the Punden, Poten and Danyang. The Poten is a sacred area of ground at [[Mount Bromo]]'s sand sea and becomes the focus of the annual Kasada Ceremony. In the Poten, it contains several buildings and enclosures, arranged in a specific composition called the Mandalas (zones). The Tenggerese also worship a host of spirits ([[ancestor worship]]). They include ''cikal bakal'', the spirits of the founders of the village, the ''roh bahurekso'', the village guardian spirits and the ''roh leluhur'', the spirits of the ancestors. Rituals to propitiate these spirits are conducted by special priests. During these rites small doll-like figures representing the spirits are clothed in batik cloth and are presented with food and drink. It is believed that the spirits partake of the essence of these offerings. The Bromo volcano is considered one of the most sacred places. If it erupts, they believe that their god is very angry. The Tenggerese give food offerings to the gods. * ''Sajenan'' is presented to the guardian deities by the priest in formal liturgy. For different occasions foods are offered as Sajenan. For instance, during weddings a cone of rice, ''Tumpeng Walagara'', is offered. It is considered to be a source of blessing for the couple and the whole village. * ''Suguhan'' are offered by ordinary Tengger Hindus to their ancestral spirits. * ''Tamping'' are food offerings to evil spirits to ward off bad luck and typically consist of meat, rice and bananas wrapped up in leaves and put at places such as cemeteries, bridges, and road intersections. The priests are called ''Dukun'' or ''Resi Pujangga''; they play a middle role in their religious worship. They are believed to possess spiritual knowledge of the gods and the spirits called Ilmu, which they carefully guard from ordinary Tenggers. Priesthood is hereditary and generally passes down from father to son. Each village has only one of these priests, with three assistants — ''Legen'', ''Sepuh'', and ''Dandan''. In the past few decades, due to overpopulation in [[Madura]], many Madurese settlers exploited the Tenggerese land by clearing some of their nature reserves and converting 2-3% (up to 10,000) of the Tenggerese to [[Islam]] in the process — particularly those in the more accessible areas in the lowlands just outside the Tengger range. Because of this Islamic [[missionary]] activity, the remaining Hindu Tenggerese asked the [[Balinese people|Balinese]] Hindus for help by reforming their culture and religion closer to the Balinese. The Indonesian government declared the Tengger mountains as the Bromo-Tengger-Semeru national park and declared that any more logging in this area is an illegal act, therefore protecting the Tenggerese from further disruption. ==Lifestyle== The Tenggerese are basically either agriculturalists or nomadic herders. The agriculturalists generally live on the lower altitudes, while the nomads live on the higher altitudes, riding on small horses.{{cite book|author=James Minahan|title=Ethnic Groups of South Asia and the Pacific: An Encyclopedia|year=2012|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=15-988-4659-0|page=324}} ==Festivals== [[File:Tengger Boys.jpeg|thumb|upright|Tenggerese children at a wedding in traditional attire.]] ===Yadnya Kasada=== {{See also|Yadnya Kasada}} The main festival of the Tenggerese is the ''Yadnya Kasada'', which lasts about a month. On the 14th day of the ''Kasada'', the Tenggerese go to Poten Bromo and ask for blessing from the main deity Hyang Widi Wasa and Mahadeva, the God of the Mountain (Mount Semeru), by offerings rice, fruit, vegetables, flowers, livestock and other local produce.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbcnordic.com/shows/lands-of-the-monsoon/|title=Lands of the Monsoon {{!}} Shows {{!}} BBC Nordic {{!}} BBC Worldwide Nordic|website=BBC Worldwide Nordic|access-date=2016-11-20}} They also see the examination of the medicine men memorizing prayers. The medicine man who passes the exam is chosen to be the spiritual leader of the Tengger tribe. The origin of this festival is a legend that dates back to the [[Majapahit]] kingdom, during the reign of King Brawijaya; the queen of the kingdom gave birth to a daughter named Roro Anteng, who married Jaka Seger, a young man from the Brahmin caste. According to the legend, Roro Anteng and Jaka Seger were among many others who fled from the tattering [[Majapahit]] kingdom during the 15th century, when the declining kingdom was in the brink of collapse while the rapid spread of [[Islam]] in Java has begun. The couple and their followers later settled in the Tengger mountains and ruled the region jointly under the title Purbawisesa Mangkurat Ing Tengger. Tradition holds belief that they are ancestors of modern Tengger people. For a few years the Tenggerese people flourished under the leadership of Jaka Seger and Roro Anteng, yet the king and queen were unhappy for they had no children. Desperate, they climbed to the top of [[Mount Bromo]] and prayed for help. Deeply moved by the couple's depth faith, the god of [[Mount Bromo]] assured them of offspring but with the condition that the youngest child be sacrificed in the crater of the volcano. After giving birth to 25 children, the time came for Roro Anteng to fulfill her part of the pledge. Though reluctant, they were threatened with catastrophe, forcing them to fulfill their pledge and comply with the god's wishes. They had no choice but to sacrifice their 25th child, Kesuma, by throwing him into the crater. In an alternate story, Kesuma was taken and consumed by the fire arising from the crater when he was about to flee from [[Mount Bromo]]. The Tengger people then started to commemorate this festival. ==See also== * [[Agama Hindu Dharma]] * [[Balinese people|Balinese]] * [[Banyumasan people|Banyumasan]] * [[Baduy people|Badui]] * [[Dayak people|Dayak]] * [[Eastern salient of Java]] * [[Javanese people|Javanese]] * [[Osing people|Osing]] * [[Toraja]] * [http://www.bbcnordic.com/shows/lands-of-the-monsoon/ BBC earth series: "Lands of the monsoon"] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://d16do.blogdetik.com/about-suku-tengger/ d16do.blogdetik.com] * [http://www.mtnforum.org/resources/library/cochj97a.htm Tourism and Conversation in the Bromo-Tengger Serumu national park] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20040807223944/http://www.petra.ac.id/english/eastjava/tourism/kasada.htm Kasada Ceremony at Mount Bromo] * [http://www.eastjava.com/books/discovery/html/bromo.html DISCOVERING EAST JAVA] {{commonscatinline|Tengger people}} {{Wikivoyage|Bromo-Tengger-Semeru National Park}} {{commons|Tengger people}} {{Ethnic groups in Indonesia}} {{Portal|Indonesia}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Indonesia]] [[Category:Hindu communities]]

revision.text:
{{npov|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox women |image = Cambodian American Traditional Dancers (22136846955).jpg |caption = |gii = 0.473 (2012) |gii_rank = 96th |matdeath = 250 (2010) |womparl = 18.1% (2012) |femed = 11.6% (2010) |womlab = 79.2% (2011) | ggg = 0.6509 (2013) | ggg_rank = 104th | ggg_ref = <ref name="ggr">{{cite web|title=The Global Gender Gap Report 2013|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GenderGap_Report_2013.pdf#page=20|publisher=World Economic Forum|pages=12–13}}</ref> }} {{Women in society sidebar}} Cambodian women are traditionally expected to be modest, soft-spoken, "light" walkers, well-mannered,<ref name=Mekong/> industrious,<ref name=Status/> belong to the household, act as the family's caregivers and caretakers<ref name=Mekong/> and financial administrators,<ref name=Status/> perform as the "preserver of the home", maintain virginity until marriage, become faithful wives,<ref name=Mekong>Chey, Elizabeth. [http://www.mekong.net/cambodia/women.htm The Status of Khmer Women], Mekong.net</ref> and act as advisors and servants to their husbands.<ref name=Status/> The "light" walking and refinement of Cambodian women is further described as being "quiet in […] movements that one cannot hear the sound of their [[silk]] skirt rustling".<ref name=Status/> As financial administrators, the women of Cambodia can be identified as having household authority at the familial level.<ref name=EC/>
In recent years, women have become more active in the traditionally male-dominated spheres of work and politics in Cambodia.
==Work== [[File:Emile gsell cambodian woman.jpg|thumb|200px|Cambodian woman]] In the wake of the [[Cambodian Civil War]], Cambodia suffered a deficit in the number of male laborers. Thus, women took over responsibilities that were commonly and principally done by Cambodian men.<ref name=Status/> Under Cambodian law, women are to receive "equal pay for equal work". In practice most women receive lower wages than their male counterparts.<ref name=Status/> During the 1990s, many "uneducated young women" from rural areas [[rural-urban migration|ventured into the city]] to work in garment factories.<ref name=Status/>
In 2004, the organisation Gender and Development for Cambodia stated that 6% of the female workforce in Cambodia is paid.<ref name=OC>[http://www.online.com.kh/~gad/Home.htm, The Status of Women in Cambodia], Gender and Development for Cambodia, online.com.kh</ref>
==Religion== {{Main|Religion in Cambodia}} [[File:BuddhistMonk02.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A [[Buddhist nun]] in Cambodia.]] Cambodian women are generally active in worshipping at [[Buddhist]] temples and participating in religious ceremonies, particularly during the ''thngai sil'' ([[English language|English]]: "holy days"). Some women not only participate as worshippers, but become [[Buddhist nun]]s (''yeay chi'') themselves, especially the widowed and the elderly.
==Education== 45% of Cambodian women were reported as being illiterate in 2004. 16% of Cambodian girls were enrolled in lower secondary schools in 2004.<ref name="OC"/> Many Cambodian girls have been kept from education due to several factors. One factor is that they are needed at home to take care of younger siblings, perform household duties, and support the head of the home. Other factors include extreme poverty, the prohibitive distance of schools from many rural houses, and sometimes even fears for their safety when traveling alone from home to school.<ref name=Status/>
Women are increasingly present in Cambodia's universities. As of 2004, 20% of graduates from universities were female.<ref name="OC"/>
==Political status== In general, from the 1980s up to the present, the number of female participants in Cambodian politics has remained low, and they are under-represented in high-level positions at both the local and national levels of the government.<ref name=Status/> Since 1993 there has been a modest rise in Cambodian women’s participation, including leadership, in non-governmental [[List of women's organizations|organization]]s focusing on the issues and [[women's rights|rights of women]].<ref name=Status/>
It was reported in 2004 that 10% of [[National Assembly of Cambodia|National Assembly]] members, 8% of Commune Council members and 7% of judges were women.<ref name="OC"/>
==Legal status== In Cambodian legislation and indeed the country's history, men and women have always technically had equal rights before the law.<ref name=Status/> This proclamation is also stated in the Constitution of Cambodia.<ref name=Status/> Women benefit from inheritance laws, wherein they can own property, they can "bring property into a marriage", they can retrieve the said property if they decide to do so, and they can easily obtain a divorce.<ref name=Status/>
==Prostitution== {{Further|Prostitution in Cambodia}}
Prostitution in Cambodia involves the hiring or forcible prostitution of both local women<ref name=Status/> and [[women from Vietnam]],<ref name=Factbook>[http://www.uri.edu/artsci/wms/hughes/cambodia.htm Cambodia], Factbook on Global Sexual Exploitation, uri.edu</ref> and is being linked to the sex trade in nearby [[Thailand]]. In part because of the spread of prostitution, around 2.8% of Cambodia’s population are infected with [[HIV]]/[[AIDS]].<ref name=Status>[http://www.seasite.niu.edu/khmer/ledgerwood/women.htm The Status of Women in Society], seasite.niu.edu</ref>
==Welfare== In rural communities, Cambodian women are susceptible to domestic violence, and in practice have "little legal recourse". <ref name=EC>[http://www.everyculture.com/Bo-Co/Cambodia.html Gender Roles and Statuses], everyculture.com</ref> Due to limited women's education, some Cambodian women are unable to protect themselves from discrimination, gender inequality, violence, and abuse, because they are not aware of their legal rights, and are also ignorant of global [[human rights]] standards.<ref name=OC/>
Gender and Development for Cambodia reported in 2004 that "23% of women have suffered physical domestic abuse".<ref name="OC"/>
==Social status== [[File:Siem Reap Server - Cambodia.JPG|thumb|right|200px|A young Cambodian [[waitress]] waiting on customers.]] Contrary to traditional Cambodian culture, young Cambodian women have been influenced by [[Western civilisation|Western]] ways in recent years. One trend is that some young female Cambodians, particularly in the capital of [[Phnom Penh]], overtly consume [[liquor]]s and other alcoholic beverages in restaurants. Other perceived Western influences include the sense of having equal rights between men and women, a sense of peer pressure, companionship, experimentation, family troubles, abandonment by a boyfriend, and increasingly, [[advertising]].<ref name=Phnom>[http://www.phnompenhpost.com/index.php/2011040648369/LIFT/women-in-cambodia-are-increasingly-becoming-social-drinkers.html Women in Cambodia are increasingly becoming social drinkers]. ''Phnom Penh Post''. April 6, 2011.</ref>
==See also== *[[Mu Sochua]] *[[Violence against women in Cambodia]] *[[Women's Media Centre of Cambodia]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *McCarthy, Casey. [http://www.un.org.kh/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=408:cambodias-first-lady-becomes-national-champion-for-womens-and-childrens-health&catid=43:latest-press-releases&Itemid=76 Cambodia's First Lady becomes National Champion for Women's and Children's Health], February 21, 2011, un.org.kh *[http://www.unaids.org/en/resources/presscentre/featurestories/2011/february/20110223cambodia/ Cambodia's First Lady appointed national champion for women’s and children’s health], Feature Story, February 23, 2011, unaids.org *[https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:QeSO1ZtBosMJ:www.no-trafficking.org/content/pdf/situation%2520of%2520women%2520in%2520cambodia%2520july%25202004.pdf+women+in+cambodia&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESj-a5zeAFgsHT4Xj8_WzAMT-fUQz9qkYrwuWj7_IHcsqVrZhEyVDhf3ahGdqpRQ3ObKC2Q-aetBzbLKHG7WqL1dMAuY7LI8H_lJhQYB0GJYsaOvF7YQtKEe8KqGxOp9LFTkP2ht&sig=AHIEtbQolRoPD5s5qXWFgN4vcImULMa8Og The Situation of Women in Cambodia], July 2004, 55 pages. *Staff. [http://www.usaid.gov/press/frontlines/fl_feb11/FL_feb11_WCamHIV.html Accelerating the Global Health Initiative: Cambodia's HIV/AIDS Efforts Put Women in the Driver's Seat], Women in Development, February/March 2011, USAID from the American people, usaid.gov *[http://cancercontrol.cancer.gov/use_what_works/Outreach_Worker_Manual.pdf Outreach Worker Manual], Cambodian Women's Health Project, January 1998, 60 pages, cancercontrol.cancer.gov
==External links== {{commons category|Women of Cambodia}} *[http://www.cwcc.org.kh/ Cambodian Women's Crisis Center (CWCC)] *[http://www.wmc.org.kh/ Women's Media Centre of Cambodia] *[http://c-who.org/index.html Cambodia Women Health Organization]

page.title: You Belong to Me: Sex, Race and Murder in the South

revision.comment: Misc citation tidying. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Infobox film | name = You Belong to Me: Sex, Race and Murder in the South | image = YBTM_POSTER-12-14_04.jpg | alt = | caption = Promotional poster | director = [[John Cork]] | producer = Judith Hagin
Kitty Potapow
Hilary Saltzman
Lisa Van Eyssen | writer = [[John Cork]] | starring = Anita Davenport
Denise Durette
Reggie Brooks | music = Geoff Gallegos | cinematography = Marq Morrison | editing = Brad Grossman | studio = Hummingbird Film Productions | distributor = Vision Films | released = {{Film date|2014|10|17|LA Femme International Film Festival{{cite web|title= LA Femme International Film Festival 2014 Documentary Features and Shorts|url=http://www.lafemme.org/documentary-features-and-shorts-2014}}|2015|02|01|VOD|{{cite news|author=Brock Seng|title=Silenced: The Story of Ruby McCollum|url=http://www.ocalastyle.com/styleadmin/newsadmin/templates/style-template.asp?articleid=2791&zoneid=34|newspaper=[[Ocala Style Magazine]]|date=January 28, 2015}}}} | runtime = 88 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''You Belong to Me: Sex, Race and Murder in the South''''' is a 2015 American [[documentary film]] produced by Hilary Saltzman, Kitty Potapow, and Jude Hagin and directed by [[John Cork]]. The film works to uncover the hidden truths of the [[Ruby McCollum]] case of 1952. McCollum, the richest African American woman in [[Suwannee County, Florida]], shot White physician and politician Clifford Leroy Adams four times with her revolver. Hagin discovered this story when meeting with the late Dr. [[James Haskins]], award-winning author and English professor at [[The University of Florida]]. Haskins provided Hagin with a copy of the [[William Bradford Huie]] book [[Ruby McCollum: Woman in the Suwannee Jail]], saying “this story needs to be told.” Upon reading Huie’s book, Hagin disagreed with the assertion that McCollum had been in a consensual, sexual relationship with Adams and that the Adams shooting was over a money dispute. “I could not get that into my head,” she said. “I could not wrap my head around the notion that an African-American woman in 1952 would willingly have a relationship with a town’s sainted physician.” Hagin’s pursuit of the truth led to an exploration of “[[paramour rights]],” the assumption that White men had the right to use Black women for sex, in the [[Jim Crow laws|Jim Crow]] South. While there had been previous books and documentaries on Ruby McCollum, '''''You Belong to Me: Sex, Race and Murder in the South''''' is the first project to get witness accounts, including interviews with McCollum’s friends and family and the last surviving juror from the trial.{{cite news|author= Paul Guzzo |title= Pinellas film producers revisit 1952 Live Oak slaying |url= http://tbo.com/pinellas-county/pinellas-producers-revisit-1952-murder-case-20141128/|newspaper=[[Tampa Bay Times]]|date= November 28, 2014}} "I wanted to get family members on both sides to tell their side of the story," Hagin said.{{cite news|author= Jason Dearen |title= Jim Crow-era shooting revisited in new documentary |url= http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sdut-jim-crow-era-shooting-revisited-in-new-documentary-2015jan01-story.html|newspaper=[[Associated Press]]|date= January 1, 2015}} The film premiered at the 2014 LA Femme International Film Festival on October 17, 2014 and was released for [[Video on demand|VOD]] on February 1, 2015 in time for [[Black History Month]]. ==Summary== On the morning of August 3rd, 1952, Ruby McCollum left her children in her car and walked into the “colored entrance” of Dr. Clifford Leroy Adams’ office and shot him four times into his body. The White doctor and state Senator-elect died on the scene while McCollum returned home to warm milk for her baby.{{cite web|title=About You Belong to Me|url=http://www.youbelongtome.net/excerpts/}} Prosecutors claimed that McCollum shot Dr. Adams in a dispute over a $116 medical bill, despite the fact that she had $1,800 in her purse and was the wealthiest Black woman in town. The judge ordered the jury to disregard McCollum’s testimony that Dr. Adams repeatedly [[rape|raped]] her and that the shooting was in [[self-defense]]. In fact, Dr. Adams fathered a daughter by McCollum, but the jury was not allowed to even look at her when she was presented as evidence of the rape. McCollum was found guilty and sentenced to death. Years later, she won an insanity plea and was released from prison in 1974. The documentary uses first-hand accounts of both the McCollum and Adams families as well as the last living juror in an attempt to uncover the truth behind the murder. Was McCollum actually insane or was she truly acting in self-defense after years of rape? '''''You Belong to Me: Sex, Race and Murder in the South''''' looks at previous conclusions and offers up its own in an effort to answer that question. ==Reception== The film received mostly positive response from critics. Mike Spain of Irish Film Critic gave it 4 out of 5 stars and wrote, “There is plenty to the story to keep the interest of the audience. One of the film’s strengths is a lot of the story is told by people who were in Live Oak at the time or had a stake in the outcome. A juror, town’s people, and Ruby’s relatives. It adds to the authenticity of the documentary.”{{cite news|author= Mike Spain|title= Movie Review: “You Belong To Me: Sex, Race And Murder In The South” Reveal Forgotten Sins |url= http://irishfilmcritic.com/movie-review-you-belong-to-me/|website=[[Irish Film Critic]]|date= May 31, 2015}} In her review for Emertainment Monthly, Emily Solomon graded the film with an A- and wrote, “What is so intriguing about the way this film is put together is how the mystery unravels. The murder is established early on in the film, with new twists and turns revealed throughout that shows McCollum’s motivation to commit in the first place.”{{cite news|author= Emily Solomon|title= Boston Film Fest Review: ‘You Belong to Me’ Unveils a Relevant Piece of History |url= http://emertainmentmonthly.com/index.php/boston-film-fest-review-you-belong-to-me-unveils-a-relevant-piece-of-history/|website=[[Emertainment Monthly]]|date= September 20, 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.youbelongtome.net/ Official Website] *{{IMDb title|3090882|You Belong to Me: Sex, Race and Murder in the South}} {{DEFAULTSORT: You Belong to Me: Sex, Race and Murder in the South}} [[Category:2015 films]] [[Category:2010s documentary films]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:Films about domestic violence]] [[Category:Documentary films about violence against women]] [[Category:Independent films]] [[Category:Racially motivated violence in the United States]] [[Category:Race-related controversies in the United States]] [[Category:Feminism]] [[Category:Sexual harassment]] [[Category:Violence against women]] [[Category:African-American history]] [[Category:Anti-black racism in the United States]] [[Category:Anti-racism]] [[Category:Black Lives Matter]] [[Category:Civil rights protests in the United States]] [[Category:Criminal justice reform in the United States]] [[Category:History of African-American civil rights]] [[Category:Race and crime in the United States]]
